repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem

Options code is messy

## Solution

Remove some very old compatibility mappings.

Related: #15484

comment_data.body:
We should add this to `news.txt`, though, in the form of a Rosetta Stone:
```
instead of
* `backspace=0` set `backspace=` (empty)
* `backspace=1` set `backspace=indent,eol`
* `backspace=2` remove (default behavior in Nvim)
* `backspace=3` set `backspace=indent,eol,nostop`
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -762,13 +762,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	When the value is empty, Vi compatible backspacing is used, none of
 	the ways mentioned for the items above are possible.
 
-	For backwards compatibility with version 5.4 and earlier:
-	value	effect	~
-	  0	same as ":set backspace=" (Vi compatible)
-	  1	same as ":set backspace=indent,eol"
-	  2	same as ":set backspace=indent,eol,start"
-	  3	same as ":set backspace=indent,eol,nostop"

comment_data.body: Would be good to replace this with a blurb about how to have spaces in a directory name
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4490,10 +4480,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	option may be relative or absolute.
 	- Use commas to separate directory names: >
 		:set path=.,/usr/local/include,/usr/include
-<	- Spaces can also be used to separate directory names (for backwards
-	  compatibility with version 3.0).  To have a space in a directory
-	  name, precede it with an extra backslash, and escape the space: >
-		:set path=.,/dir/with\\\ space

comment_data.body: I've changed the code so spaces just work as normal.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4490,10 +4480,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	option may be relative or absolute.
 	- Use commas to separate directory names: >
 		:set path=.,/usr/local/include,/usr/include
-<	- Spaces can also be used to separate directory names (for backwards
-	  compatibility with version 3.0).  To have a space in a directory
-	  name, precede it with an extra backslash, and escape the space: >
-		:set path=.,/dir/with\\\ space

comment_data.body: May still be worth mentioning here? Or at least in the `news.txt` entry.

@@ -4490,10 +4480,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	option may be relative or absolute.
 	- Use commas to separate directory names: >
 		:set path=.,/usr/local/include,/usr/include
-<	- Spaces can also be used to separate directory names (for backwards
-	  compatibility with version 3.0).  To have a space in a directory
-	  name, precede it with an extra backslash, and escape the space: >
-		:set path=.,/dir/with\\\ space

comment_data.body: And maybe add a test for correctly handling dirs with spaces?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4490,10 +4480,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	option may be relative or absolute.
 	- Use commas to separate directory names: >
 		:set path=.,/usr/local/include,/usr/include
-<	- Spaces can also be used to separate directory names (for backwards
-	  compatibility with version 3.0).  To have a space in a directory
-	  name, precede it with an extra backslash, and escape the space: >
-		:set path=.,/dir/with\\\ space

comment_data.body: There aren't really any existing tests for backupdir using multiple values.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4490,10 +4480,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	option may be relative or absolute.
 	- Use commas to separate directory names: >
 		:set path=.,/usr/local/include,/usr/include
-<	- Spaces can also be used to separate directory names (for backwards
-	  compatibility with version 3.0).  To have a space in a directory
-	  name, precede it with an extra backslash, and escape the space: >
-		:set path=.,/dir/with\\\ space

comment_data.body: (I meant single value, but one that includes spaces)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4490,10 +4480,6 @@ A jump table for the options with a short description can be found at |Q_op|.
 	option may be relative or absolute.
 	- Use commas to separate directory names: >
 		:set path=.,/usr/local/include,/usr/include
-<	- Spaces can also be used to separate directory names (for backwards
-	  compatibility with version 3.0).  To have a space in a directory
-	  name, precede it with an extra backslash, and escape the space: >
-		:set path=.,/dir/with\\\ space

@@ -68,8 +68,9 @@ func Test_backspace_ctrl_u()
         \ "8 this shouldn't be deleted (not touched yet)"])
   call cursor(2, 1)
 
-  " set compatible
-  set backspace=2
+  " " set compatible
+  " set backspace=2 2
+  set backspace=indent,eol,start"

comment_data.body: This should probably go in vim_diff as well
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -51,6 +51,16 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
   • `vim.json.null` is redundant with `vim.NIL`.
   • `vim.json.array_mt` (and related) is redundant with `vim.empty_dict()`.
 
+• Removed some Vim 5.0<= option compatibilities:
+  • |'backspace'| no longer supports number values. Instead:
+    • for `backspace=0` set `backspace=` (empty)
+    • for `backspace=1` set `backspace=indent,eol`
+    • for `backspace=2` set `backspace=indent,eol,start` (default behavior in Nvim)
+    • for `backspace=3` set `backspace=indent,eol,nostop`
+  • paths in |'backupdir'|, |'path'| and |'cdpath'| can no longer be separated with
+    spaces.
+  • |'directory'| will no longer remove a `>` at the start of the option.
+

@@ -68,8 +68,9 @@ func Test_backspace_ctrl_u()
         \ "8 this shouldn't be deleted (not touched yet)"])
   call cursor(2, 1)
 
-  " set compatible
-  set backspace=2
+  " " set compatible
+  " set backspace=2 2

@@ -201,7 +201,8 @@ func Test_virtual_replace()
   enew!
   exe "normal a\nabcdefghi\njk\tlmn\n    opq	rst\n\<C-D>uvwxyz"
   call cursor(1,1)
-  set ai bs=2
+  " set ai bs=2
+  set ai bs=indent,eol,auto

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
  • paths in |'backupdir'|, |'path'| and |'cdpath'| can no longer be separated with
    spaces (but paths themselves may contain spaces now).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -51,6 +51,16 @@ The following changes may require adaptations in user config or plugins.
   • `vim.json.null` is redundant with `vim.NIL`.
   • `vim.json.array_mt` (and related) is redundant with `vim.empty_dict()`.
 
+• Removed some Vim 5.0<= option compatibilities:
+  • |'backspace'| no longer supports number values. Instead:
+    • for `backspace=0` set `backspace=` (empty)
+    • for `backspace=1` set `backspace=indent,eol`
+    • for `backspace=2` set `backspace=indent,eol,start` (default behavior in Nvim)
+    • for `backspace=3` set `backspace=indent,eol,nostop`
+  • paths in |'backupdir'|, |'path'| and |'cdpath'| can no longer be separated with
+    spaces.

comment_data.body:
bars `|...|` are not needed to link to options.
```suggestion
  'backupdir': paths can no longer be separated with spaces.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -623,10 +623,17 @@ Highlight groups:
 Options:
   *'aleph'* *'al'*
   antialias
+  |'backspace'| no longer supports number values. Instead:
+    - for `backspace=0` set `backspace=` (empty)
+    - for `backspace=1` set `backspace=indent,eol`
+    - for `backspace=2` set `backspace=indent,eol,start` (default behavior in Nvim)
+    - for `backspace=3` set `backspace=indent,eol,nostop`
   *'balloondelay'* *'bdlay'*
   *'ballooneval'* *'beval'* *'noballooneval'* *'nobeval'*
   *'balloonexpr'* *'bexpr'*
+  |'backupdir'|: paths can no longer be separated with spaces.

comment_regular_data.body:
`Test_backspace_option` oldtest specifically tests the number conversion and can be removed (commented out/skipped).
 
First `OptionSet` functionaltest just uses `backspace as an example, IIUC; can just be replaced by another (saner) option; second one can just be removed as it also tests the removed conversion.

> Problem
> Options code is messy _and complicates important work such as adding support for dictionary options_.
I'm just a curious bystander: why were some tests removed and other commented out?
the `oldtest` are taken from Vim; only commenting them out makes it easier to port future patches that touch them.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(options)!: remove compatible behaviours for vim 5.0 and earlier
